summary:
But, why is the admin slow?

This is the general outline I'm working from so far. I think this could
change slightly as I develop the talk, but this outline conveys the
general theme.

Introduction and display of basic django-debug-toolbar usage (2 min)

Things the admin does well (3 min)

Makes development very fast For many use cases, it "does the right
thing" automatically. For example, modifying the HTML in a callable
won't cause new queries. What can sneak up on you (5 min)

Having lots of related items visible in the list view Using
list\_select\_related Overriding queryset for additional select\_related
and prefetch\_related options What to avoid in callables (3 min)

Queries that will be executed on every row The default widgets for
many-to-many and foreign key fields (3 min)

What widgets to use to replace the defaults based on how many options
you have in your database Custom aggregates in the list view (i.e.
custom querysets) (3 min)

When this is a good idea When this is too slow and you need other
options More general performance improvements through caching (3-5 min)

Django's caching framework Caching with third-party packages / tools
Custom caching with Redis Questions (Remaining time)
title: But, why is the admin slow?
